docs.lead_paragraph: The plaintive notes of a clarinet hung in the air as several dozen people filed into a small meeting room at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. Some sat solemnly, clutching tissues, their heads bowed in silent prayer. Others tearfully embraced old friends. Each had come to mourn the end of a life, the death of a dream. In the last year, they had all been expecting babies and had lost them -- to miscarriage, abortion or stillbirth. But in the midst of their grief, they said, they could find no established way to mark these pregnancies that had ended only in sorrow.

headline.main: For Lost Pregnancies, New Rites of Mourning

docs.abstract: Women and men are resorting to growing array of rituals to cope with loss of pregnancy--loss many feel may not be properly understood or acknowledged by family, friends, health-care workers and religious leaders; rites include formal funeral services, quiet meditations and kinds of individualized rituals that have become more popular as alternative spiritual practices gain greater acceptance; new movement is driven in large part by growing numbers of older women who, having delayed childbearing, find themselves facing great difficulty trying to conceive and carry healthy babies to term; is also result of society's changing perception of when fetus becomes child--change prompted by medical advances that have both reduced age at which premature babies can be kept alive and allowed parents to watch fetus grow in womb; mourning program offered at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day he was to have what he would later call his ''meeting with the devil,'' Randy Warren woke up early. It was the last day of April 1997, and Warren had spent a restless night in a hotel at the Toronto airport, two hours from his home, awaiting the morning arrival of two strangers, businessmen from New Jersey. The strangers were executives of the Celgene Corporation, a tiny pharmaceutical company that is seeking Government approval to market thalidomide, the world's most notorious agent of birth defects. Warren, the founder and chief executive officer of the Thalidomide Victims Association of Canada, had come to provide these men with living proof of their product's ruinous past.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE message of Cheryl Dews-Brewton is simple but not always easy to act on: when life throws you an extraordinary number of lemons, get professional help. The Yonkers resident knows first hand. Over the last 11 years, she lost a 36-year-old brother to heart disease and a 58-year-old brother-in-law to cancer. Her daughter, Jihan, was born with a congenital heart defect and despite surgery, she died at 18 months. Mrs. Dews-Brewton's other brother died at 37 and her father-in-law died after a long bout with bone cancer. Her mother died from an enlarged heart condition and her mother-in-law died from diabetic complications.

headline.main: Q&A/Cheryl Dews-Brewton; When Troubles Mount, Seek Outside Help

docs.abstract: Yonkers resident Cheryl Dews-Brewton, in interview with Donna Greene, discusses how Center for Preventive Psychiatry helped her after her 18-month-old daughter, Jihan, died from congenital heart defect and she came down with muscular sclerosis; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As scientists and academics batted around some esoteric notions at a recent conference on genetics, a 69-year-old bearded man stood up, made some vague and rambling statements, then issued a grandiose claim: He would soon start cloning humans.

headline.main: Eccentric's Hubris Set Off Global Frenzy Over Cloning

docs.abstract: One of the more interesting thing about the plans for human cloning announced by Dr Richard Seed is how an eccentric physicist with no job, no money and--most scientists agree--no chance of success became such a huge national figure; his sudden notoriety speaks volumes about the willingness of news media, led by National Public Radio, to take him seriously and about nation's fascination and anxiety over genetic technology at a time when virtually everything seems technologically possible; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As scientists and academics batted around some esoteric notions at a recent conference on genetics, a 69-year-old bearded man stood up, made some vague and rambling statements, then issued a grandiose claim:    He would soon start cloning humans.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a struggling SoHo artist, it was the sale of eight watercolors after three dry decades. For a Long Island lawyer, it was his wife's pregnancy with twins after five barren years. And for a single mother in Queens, it was the simple realization that things could always be worse. Like hundreds of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, they were moved to give by a belief that good fortune should be spread to others.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Spreading Good Fortune By Helping Others in Need

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; donors to fund discuss reasons behind their contributions (M)
